title: 103_hr4600
content: Section 1 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to allow expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. The President can propose rescinding budget authority or repealing targeted tax benefits, with a special message to Congress including a draft bill specifying the amounts to be rescinded. These funds cannot be proposed for rescission again. The President can propose rescinding budget authority or repealing targeted tax benefits through a special message to Congress, including a draft bill specifying the amounts to be rescinded. This process includes a Deficit Reduction Account and a time limit for repealing targeted tax benefits. The President can propose rescinding budget authority by sending a special message to Congress with a draft bill specifying the amount, accounts affected, reasons for rescission, and estimated effects. The President can propose rescinding budget authority by sending a special message to Congress with a draft bill specifying the amount, accounts affected, reasons for rescission, and estimated effects, including the effect on outlays and receipts in each fiscal year. The special message must also include all facts, circumstances, and considerations relating to the proposed rescission and its impact on the objects, purposes, and programs for which the budget authority is provided. Additionally, for the proposed repeal of targeted tax benefits, specific information is required as outlined in subparagraphs (C), (D), and (E). Before the second legislative day after receiving a special message, the majority or minority leader must introduce the draft bill. If not, any member can introduce it on the third legislative day. The bill will be referred to the appropriate committee for review and must be reported without substantive revision. The bill must be reported by the appropriate committee without substantive revision within the seventh legislative day after receiving a special message. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar. Members of the House of Representatives can move to strike proposed rescissions or repeals with support from 49 other members. The House of Representatives must vote on final passage of the bill within 10 legislative days after its introduction. If passed, the bill will be sent to the Senate within one day. Members can move to strike proposed rescissions with support from 49 other members. The House of Representatives must vote on final passage of the bill within 10 legislative days after its introduction. A motion to proceed to consider a bill under this section is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. It is not in order to move to recommit the bill or reconsider the vote. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to the procedure for bills under this section, decided without debate. Consideration of a bill under this section follows House rules, not under suspension or special rules. Bills transmitted to the Senate are referred to the appropriate committee for reporting without substantive revision. The bill must be reported by the Senate committee within seven legislative days, or the committee will be discharged. Members can move to strike proposed rescissions or repeals with support from 14 others. Amendments must reduce the Deficit Reduction Account if striking a proposed rescission. The Reduction Account under section 314 allows for privileged and non-debatable motions in the Senate to proceed to consider a bill. Debate on the bill and related motions shall not exceed 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders or their designees. Debate in the Senate on motions or appeals related to a bill under this section is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. The minority leader controls time in opposition if the bill manager supports the motion. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders. Motion to further limit debate on a bill is not debatable. Debate on motions or appeals related to a bill under this section is limited to 1 hour in the Senate. No amendments or divisions are allowed, and any rescinded budget authority must be made available for obligation the day after rejection by either House. The section outlines the process for repealing targeted tax benefits through a special message to Congress. Any benefit proposed for repeal will be deemed repealed unless either House rejects the bill within a specified period. Definitions for terms like "appropriation Act" and "legislative day" are provided. The text discusses the provision of different treatment to specific taxpayers or classes, excluding benefits based on general demographic conditions. It also amends Section 904 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 and makes conforming amendments to Section 1011. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to repeal certain paragraphs and make changes to various sections, including Section 1014 and Section 1015. These amendments remove references to establishing reserves and reservations. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove references to rescission bills and make changes to subsections (a), (b), (c), and (d) by striking certain phrases. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended in subsection (d)(2) by removing and amending certain sentences related to debate on debatable motions or appeals in connection with an impoundment resolution. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended by removing certain sentences related to debate on debatable motions or appeals in connection with an impoundment resolution. Additionally, paragraphs (4), (5), (6), and (7) of paragraph (d) are struck. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 was amended to expedite the consideration of proposed rescissions of budget authority under H.R. 4600, passed by the House of Representatives on July 14, 1994.
